(Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MinValue] [Arithmetic Underflow] When MinValue.Seconds (-62135596800L) is used in subtraction operations for duration calculations, can underflow occur enabling negative time periods for voting lockups? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MinValue] [Protobuf Serialization] Can the Nanos=0 and Seconds=-62135596800L in MinValue lead to invalid protobuf encoding that crashes contracts expecting positive timestamps? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MinValue] [Cross-Contract Comparison] When MinValue is used as StartTimestamp in voting registration, can cross-contract timestamp comparisons fail due to negative Seconds value, allowing votes before registration? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MinValue] [New Instance Creation] Does creating a new Timestamp instance every time MinValue is accessed (non-cached) allow attackers to DOS by forcing repeated object allocations in tight loops? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MinValue] [Timezone Edge Case] Is the MinValue timestamp (0001-01-01T00:00:00Z) correctly handled across all timezone conversions, or can local time operations cause it to become invalid? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MinValue] [Comparison Logic] When MinValue is compared with current block timestamps in consensus validation, can the extreme negative value cause comparison operator failures or unexpected behavior? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MaxValue] [Integer Overflow] Can the MaxValue Seconds (253402300799L) cause overflow when used in addition operations for voting end time calculations, wrapping to negative values? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MaxValue] [Nanos Boundary] Is the MaxValue Nanos=999999999 correctly validated as the maximum valid nanoseconds value, or can operations exceed this causing invalid timestamps? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MaxValue] [Duration Overflow] When MaxValue is used in duration calculations (MaxValue - currentTime), can the resulting duration overflow long.MaxValue causing arithmetic exceptions? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MaxValue] [Protobuf Limits] Does MaxValue (9999-12-31T23:59:59.999999999Z) exceed any Protobuf Timestamp wire format limits when serialized for cross-chain communication? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MaxValue] [Voting Period DOS] When MaxValue is used as EndTimestamp in voting registration, can this create infinitely-long voting periods that prevent proper vote settlement and reward distribution? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MaxValue] [Year 9999 Edge Case] Is the MaxValue year 9999 handled correctly in all date arithmetic operations, or can calendar library assumptions about modern dates cause crashes? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/TimestampHelper.cs] [Property: MaxValue] [Comparison Edge Case] When MaxValue is compared with real timestamps in vote expiration checks, can rounding errors in Nanos (999999999) cause premature or delayed expirations? (Medium)
